title: Christopher Le
text:
Hello everyone! I’m Christopher Le, a UCLA senior graduating Spring 2026. I build data‑driven models and tools at the intersection of inference and physical systems, with interests in aerospace and sustainability. In my free time, I enjoy exploring local city spots, embarking on solo travel, and attending indie music concerts, where I have the creative freedom to connect socially with people from diverse backgrounds and interests.
Check out my resume here!

title: Project 3
text:
Bidirectional Soft Actuator Voltage Control System
Context: Embedded Timing & Signal Measurement Circuit Adaptive deformation control using MOSFET switching and PWM voltage modulation
Year: 2022-23

Problem
Enable selective and variable deformation in different regions of a bidirectional soft robotic actuator by controlling voltage delivery to multiple channels from a single power source through voltage manipulation.


Approach
Designed a multi-channel power distribution circuit using N-channel MOSFETs as high-side and low-side switches
Implemented pulse-width modulation (PWM) to produce different effective output voltages from a constant supply
Created an interface to independently modulate actuator regions, enabling tunable expansion patterns
Validated actuator deformation response under variable duty cycle control


Results
Achieved smooth, fine-grain control of actuator shape and motion, allowing directional bending and surface profile changes without redesigning the actuator structure.


My contribution
Circuit design, switching architecture, PWM control strategy, hardware testing


Tech
N-channel MOSFETs, resistive gate networks, bench power supply, Arduino Microcontroller - PWM source, soft actuator material (silicone-based)


Keywords
soft robotics, actuator control, voltage modulation, MOSFET switching, PWM signal processing


Demonstration



Tinkercad Actuator Circuit Design - View 1





Soft Actuator Circuit – View 2





Soft Actuator Circuit – View 3

title: Project 2
text:
Context: Undergraduate research in optical systems and robotics deformation analysis
Year: 2022 - present



Existing 3D mapping methods like photogrammetry, LIDAR, and 3D scanning struggle with:

Accurate real-time measurement of deformable soft robotics.
Handling translucent or non-opaque surfaces





Designed a custom setup combining 2-axis motorized stage with laser displacement sensor
Integrated stepper motors controlled via a microcontroller
Began developing software to sync coordinate collection and motor control.





System prototype under development of preliminary design.
Presented research to American Physical Society (APS) March Conference




Programmed microcontroller for stepper motor control and sensor integration.
Created system schematic and poster visualization.



2-axis stepper motor platform, Arduino microcontroller, Laser displacement sensor



soft robotics, real-time tracking, optical measurement, deformation mapping, embedded systems, computer vision



Poster
Video



American Physical Society March Conference

title: Project 1
text:
Reaction Time Game
Context: Embedded Timing & Signal Measurement Circuit
Year: 2024

Problem
Design a low-cost, self-contained system to measure human reaction time with millisecond accuracy.


Approach
Constructed a 1 kHz clock signal using a 555 timer in astable mode
Designed input detection using discrete logic components
Implemented display and timing readout for reaction measurement


Results
Achieved stable millisecond-level timing with repeatable reaction measurements across users.


My contribution
Hardware design, timing circuit calibration, data capture


Tech
555 Timer IC, discrete logic gates, LEDs, push-button input, breadboard prototyping, oscilloscope


Keywords
embedded circuits, timing systems, measurement instrumentation


Demonstration
Video 1
Video 2
Video 3
